journal-meta.journal-title: World Journal for Pediatric and Congenital Heart Surgery

subj-group.subject: Proceedings of the Seventh International Conference on Pediatric Mechanical Circulatory Support Systems and Pediatric Cardiopulmonary Perfusion

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Anesthesiology and Critical Care Medicine, The Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia, Philadelphia, PA, USA

author-notes.corresp: Maryam Y. Naim, Department of Anesthesiology and Critical Care Medicine, The Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia, 34th and Civic Center Boulevard, Philadelphia, PA 19104, USA Email: naim@email.chop.edu

abstract.p: In October 2010, the American Heart Association released updated guidelines for cardiopulmonary resuscitation and emergency cardiovascular care. Major changes in the pediatric basic and advanced life support guidelines are reviewed in this article. The use of extracorporeal membrane oxygenation in cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) is also reviewed including the results of two recent large studies and preliminary reports on long-term neurologic outcome of survivors.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In October 2010, the American Heart Association (AHA) released updated guidelines for cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR), and emergency cardiovascular care. Based on new evidence, the updated guidelines for pediatric basic 1 and advanced 2 life support reinforce the emphasis on high-quality basic CPR and recommend few major changes compared to the 2005 guidelines. Some of these key recommendations and their rationale will be reviewed in this article. The use of extracorporeal CPR (E-CPR) for children with cardiac arrest refractory to standard resuscitative measures continues to increase. 3,4 New research on this lifesaving technology will also be reviewed.

sec.title: The Extent of the Problem
sec.p: The incidence of pediatric out-of-hospital cardiac arrest (OHCA) is approximately 8 per 100,000 person years, 5 and less than 10% of patients 5,6 survive to hospital discharge. The incidence of pediatric in-hospital cardiac arrest (IHCA) is variable and has been previously reported to range from approximately 1% to 2% of all pediatric intensive care unit (PICU) admissions. 7,8 Outcomes from pediatric IHCA range from 22% to 36% survival to hospital discharge. 9 –11

sec.title: What is New in Pediatric Basic Life Support?
Major changes
sec.p: Major changes to the pediatric basic life support algorithms 1 include, a change in the sequence of CPR for pulseless cardiac arrest from A-B-C (airway, breathing/ventilation, chest compressions) to C-A-B (chest compressions/ventilation, airway, breathing), with initiation of CPR with chest compressions rather than rescue breaths. The main rationale for this change is to prevent a delay in initiation of CPR. It takes laypersons and inexperienced professionals up to an average of 14 seconds to open the airway and initiate ventilation. 12 In addition, pulse checks by lay rescuers are unreliable and no longer recommended, with recommendation to initiate CPR if a victim has no breathing, or abnormal, gasping respiration.

sec.title: High-quality CPR
sec.p: The guidelines continue to emphasize high-quality CPR.

sec.title: Depth of compressions
sec.p: Inadequate chest compression depth is common during CPR. 13,14 In a recent quantitative analysis of CPR quality in children and adolescents with IHCA, AHA targets for depth and rate were not achieved 36.1% and 48% of the time, respectively. The updated guidelines reemphasize to “push hard” to a depth of approximately 1½ inches (4 cm) in infants and approximately 2 inches (5 cm) in children, or at least one third of the anterior–posterior dimension of the chest. New evidence with measurement of optimal depth of compressions with analysis of chest tomography scans of infants and children shows that the previous recommendation to push to one half was too deep 15 and may not be achievable.

sec.title: Leaning, interruptions, and overventilation
sec.p: In addition, 2010 guidelines increase emphasis on avoiding “leaning” on the chest that prevents full recoil of the chest and refilling of the heart, avoiding interruptions of CPR (eg, charge the defibrillator during chest compressions), and avoidance of overventilation.

sec.title: Automated external defibrillator use in infants
sec.p: The 2010 guidelines also address the use of automated external defibrillators (AEDs) for infants with a shockable rhythm that is ventricular fibrillation or pulseless ventricular tachycardia. Manual defibrillators are preferred to AEDs in infants, however if a manual defibrillator is not available an AED with a dose attenuator can be used. Based on a recent case report, if neither a manual defibrillator nor an AED with dose attenuator is available, defibrillation with an AED without a dose attenuator may be safe and effective in infants 16 with cardiac arrest secondary to a shockable rhythm.

sec.title: Compression-only CPR
sec.p: In adults with witnessed cardiac arrest of presumed cardiac etiology, chest-compression-only CPR by lay rescuers has been shown to be associated with increased survival compared with no CPR and equivalent to conventional CPR with rescue breathing. 17 The updated 2010 adult basic life support guidelines recommend hands-only CPR by untrained lay rescuers of adults with cardiac arrest. 18

A study done in children in Japan comparing chest-compression-only CPR to conventional CPR showed that survivors of arrest from noncardiac causes (71%) had better neurological outcomes with conventional CPR with rescue breathing, compared to those receiving bystander chest-compression-only CPR. In children who had arrests from cardiac causes (29%), there was no difference in neurologic outcome between children who received conventional CPR compared to compression-only CPR, 19 but both CPR groups had better survival than those who did not receive bystander CPR at all. As asphyxial arrests are common in children, the 2010 pediatric guidelines recommend conventional CPR for the lay rescuer, unless the rescuer is not trained, not willing, or not confident in providing the rescue breaths.

sec.title: What is New in Pediatric Advanced Life Support?
End-Tidal carbon dioxide monitoring
sec.p: End-tidal carbon dioxide (ETCO2) monitoring is recommended to confirm tracheal intubation, as well as quantitative capnography during CPR to monitor and guide the quality of CPR. End-tidal CO2 is reflective of pulmonary blood flow, it increases with interventions that increase cardiac output during CPR and can identify return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC), 20,21 without the need to interrupt chest compressions.

sec.title: Cricoid pressure
sec.p: Cricoid pressure is no longer routinely recommended for tracheal intubation, as it may interfere with the speed or ease of intubation. 22

sec.title: Echocardiography
sec.p: Consideration of echocardiography has also been recommended as a monitoring tool during CPR, to identify a reversible cause for example, pericardial tamponade. 23,24 The caveat to the use of echocardiography is a strong emphasis on continuing to perform high-quality CPR with minimization of CPR interruptions and availability of appropriately trained personnel.

sec.title: Newborn resuscitation
sec.p: Newborns with cardiac arrest receive chest compressions at a ratio of 3:1 (chest compressions–breaths) in the newborn nursery or neonatal intensive care unit, 25 however if the cardiac arrest is of primary cardiac origin, the new pediatric guidelines recommend a ratio of 15:2 in newborns, regardless of location.

sec.title: Medication use
sec.p: There is continuing emphasis on the lack of benefit of routine calcium and/or bicarbonate administration during CPR, with new evidence that it may be harmful. 26 Etomidate use, especially in children with sepsis, 27,28 is discouraged.

sec.title: Special resuscitation situations
sec.p: Special resuscitation situations that have been addressed in the updated guidelines include septic shock, hypovolemic shock, trauma, the single-ventricle patient, and pulmonary hypertension. The emphasis for all these situations in children is standard resuscitation.

sec.title: The single-ventricle patient
sec.p:
In children with shunted single-ventricle physiology in cardiac arrest, along with standard resuscitative measures, if shunt occlusion event is suspected consideration of bolus heparin therapy is recommended. (At our institution a dose of 100 units/kg is administered intravenously during CPR if a shunt occlusion event is suspected.) In infants prior to stage 1 in a prearrest low cardiac output condition, with a high ratio of pulmonary blood flow to systemic blood flow, increasing partial pressure of CO2 with controlled hypoventilation or inspired CO2
29 may be considered. In children with a Fontan or hemi-Fontan/bidirectional Glenn physiology in a prearrest low cardiac output condition, hypoventilation may improve oxygen delivery, 30 and negative pressure ventilation may improve cardiac output. 31 (At our institution, we use the NEV-100 [Lifecare Inc, Lafayette, CO, USA] ventilator for this indication.)

Monitoring with near infrared spectroscopy 32 and systemic venous oxygen saturations 33 may detect changes in hemodynamics that may be helpful in detecting impending cardiac arrest. Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) should be considered before or early during cardiac arrest for children following a stage I operation, 34 and with Fontan physiology, 35 it is unclear whether patients with hemi-Fontan or bidirectional Glenn physiology benefit from ECMO. Cannulation in patients with hemi-Fontan and Glenn physiology is challenging because of the separation of systemic venous return with the superior vena cava to pulmonary artery and inferior vena cava to right atrium. In addition, pulmonary blood flow is passive in patients with hemi-Fontan and bidirectional Glenn physiology. Increased intrathoracic pressure during CPR limits pulmonary blood flow and increases central venous pressures, decreasing cerebral perfusion pressure leading to an increased risk of neurologic injury during CPR.

sec.title: Pulmonary hypertension
sec.p: A standard pediatric advanced life support (PALS) approach with conventional CPR should be administered to children with pulmonary hypertension, with special consideration to correcting hypercarbia, adequacy of preload (fluid bolus administration), reinstitution of pulmonary hypertensive therapies (if they were discontinued prior to the event), inhaled nitric oxide, inhaled prostacyclin, or an intravenous bolus of prostacyclin. Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation may have benefit for reversible conditions, if it is initiated early in the resuscitation36 and in conjunction with high-quality basic life support.

sec.title: Postresuscitation care
sec.p: Recommendations for postresuscitation care include close monitoring and support to avoid hyperthermia, hypotension, hypoglycemia, hyperglycemia, hypoxemia, or hyperoxia, and achieve normocarbia. A goal-directed and meticulous approach is recommended. Increasing evidence is emerging on the deleterious effects of hyperoxia following cardiac arrest, 37 the new guidelines have addressed this by recommending titration of oxygen following ROSC to an oxyhemoglobin saturation of 94% to 98%.

Careful consideration of therapeutic hypothermia in comatose children following cardiac arrest 38,39 is recommended but cannot be strongly recommended until completion of the ongoing international “Therapeutic Hypothermia after Pediatric Cardiac Arrest (THAPCA)” multicenter trial. 40 Additional neuroprotective strategies mentioned include aggressive management of hyperthermia and postischemic seizures.

sec.title: Sudden unexplained death in a child
sec.p: For children who have had sudden unexplained deaths, previous medical and family history should be reviewed, as well as previous electrocardiograms to rule out a channelopathy. A complete autopsy with genetic analysis should be performed, and family members should be referred to a center with expertise in arrhythmias. 41

sec.title: Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation in CPR (E-CPR)
sec.p: The use of rescue ECMO in children following cardiac arrest was described by del Nido and colleagues in 1992, in 11 children with cardiac arrest following open heart surgery, with 64% early survival with no long-term cardiac or neurologic sequelae. 42 In 1998, the Children’s Hospital of Boston reported their use of a team for rapid deployment ECMO in 11 children with congenital heart disease following cardiac arrest and showed shorter duration of cardiac arrest (55 vs 90 minutes) and improved survival (64% vs 27%) compared to historical controls. 43 Deployment occurred with a rapid-resuscitation ECMO circuit maintained in the ICU, and a rapid deployment team consisting of a cardiologist, cardiac surgeon, cardiac nursing, and respiratory care department ECMO specialists. Other institutions subsequently published their experience with E-CPR. 8,44 The Hospital for Sick Children in Toronto reported the use of ECMO within 24 hours following cardiac arrest in a mixed PICU population was associated with reduced hospital mortality. 8 The Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia reported that children with heart disease were more likely to survive compared to children with other medical conditions, 44 and that ECMO is considered lifesaving after stage 1 operation especially in infants with reversible conditions like acute shunt thrombosis and transient ventricular dysfunction. 34

sec.title: New E-CPR outcome studies
sec.p: Two recent large studies on E-CPR from the Extracorporeal Life Support Organization (ELSO) database 3 and National Registry of Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (NRCPR) 4 have shown increased use of E-CPR in children over time with more patients receiving E-CPR more recently. However, there has been no increase in percentage survival over time but an overall increase in survivors over time.

The ELSO study included 110 centers with 14 international centers between 1992 and 2005, 682 pediatric patients had E-CPR, of which 499 were cardiac, with a 38% survival to hospital discharge. Patients with newborn respiratory disease (including congenital diaphragmatic hernia, meconium aspiration syndrome and neonatal respiratory distress syndrome) and cardiac disease had higher survival rates compared to children with sepsis, pediatric respiratory disease, and accidental injury. Complications associated with an increased risk of death included central nervous system (CNS) injury, renal injury, a pH <7.2, pulmonary hemorrhage, CPR on ECMO, gastrointestinal hemorrhage, and hyperbilirubinemia.

In the NRCPR study of 199 E-CPR events over a seven-year period, there was a 43.7% survival to hospital discharge, with cardiac patients more likely to survive compared to noncardiac patients.Of the survivors, 95% had favorable neurologic outcomes on pediatric cerebral performance category scores at the time of hospital discharge. Renal insufficiency and metabolic and electrolyte abnormalities with acidosis and administration of sodium bicarbonate or tromethamine were associated with a worse outcome. Interestingly, 5 of 7 survivors who had CPR for more than 90 minutes prior to ECMO cannulation had a good neurologic outcome.

In another study from Toronto, 45 acceptable survival and neurologic outcomes were seen in children after prolonged cardiac arrest (up to 95 minutes) with children with favorable outcomes having a comparable duration of CPR (46 minutes) compared to children with an unfavorable outcome (41 minutes). The key to good outcome in these cases was most likely high-quality CPR, with prompt restoration of circulation with ECMO and excellent postresuscitative care.

In another report from the ELSO database on 492 patients with cardiac disease who underwent E-CPR, 46 survival to hospital discharge was 42%, with mortality associated with single-ventricle physiology, the stage I procedure, extreme acidosis prior to ECMO, renal injury, neurologic injury, and duration of ECMO support. Right carotid artery cannulation was associated with decreased mortality risk. This is most likely secondary to the ability to perform high-quality CPR without interruption with neck cannulation, compared to transthoracic cannulation.

Recently, The Children’s Hospital of Boston reported their cardiac E-CPR outcomes in 172 patients, 47 with a 51% survival to hospital discharge and 75% patients with favorable neurologic outcomes at hospital discharge. Mortality was associated with noncardiac structural abnormalities, severe metabolic acidosis, blood primed circuit, and long ECMO duration. The re-primed circuit in the ICU for rapid deployment was colloid primed in the majority of patients, with blood priming occurring when the circuit was being prepared for elective cannulation for significant refractory cardiorespiratory dysfunction prior to cardiac arrest.

sec.title: Neurological outcome after E-CPR
sec.p: Long-term neurologic outcome data are lacking in survivors of E-CPR. In the ELSO database, 48 acute neurologic injury was reported in 22% of the 682 patients who had E-CPR. Acute neurological injury was defined in the ELSO database as brain death, cerebral infarction, or intracranial hemorrhage determined by ultrasound or computerized tomography imaging of the head; 11% had brain death, 7% cerebral infarction, and 7% intracranial hemorrhage, with an in-hospital mortality for patients with acute neurologic injury of 89%. However, this manuscript did not report any medium (at hospital discharge) or long-term (following index hospitalization) neurologic outcome data as functional outcome at discharge and at long-term follow-up after index hospitalization was not collected by ELSO.

Although recent papers have reported high percentages of children with good neurologic outcome at the time of discharge, 4,45,47 this most likely does not represent true long-term neurologic injury, as the majority of survivors are young infants. Ibrahim et al 49 reported long-term follow-up (median 42 months) of pediatric cardiac patients requiring mechanical circulatory support (ECMO and ventricular assist device). The study was conducted using telephone interviews and showed that 3 of 17 patients who had no neurologic impairment had received CPR; however one third of the patients with neurologic impairment had received CPR.

In another study looking at long-term neurodevelopmental outcomes of 14 infants supported with ECMO following cardiac surgery, 50 75% of patients had normal neuromotor and 50% had a normal cognitive outcome, however E-CPR patients were not reported in this paper. In a small study from Canada, 51 looking at two-year survival, mental and motor outcomes after cardiac ECMO in 16 children, 50% of ECMO survivors had mental delay, which was significant in 2 out of 5 E-CPR survivors.

sec.title: Cost-benefit of E-CPR
sec.p: The use of ECMO can be supported by the assumption that there is zero survival after cardiac arrest that is refractory to prolonged conventional CPR and PALS. Thus, any intact neurologic survival with E-CPR under these conditions represents improved outcome. The cost-benefit of this therapy has been questioned especially in terms of long-term neurologic disability and complex ongoing care of survivors. 52
A recent study showed that the cost-utility for salvage ECMO was within a range of accepted cost efficacy. 53

sec.title: Patient selection
sec.p: With regard to patient outcomes and cost utility, patient selection is a key issue. In the ELSO retrospective review of E-CPR, 77% of patients with sepsis, 79% with pediatric respiratory disease, and 82% of accidental injury died (compared with 50% neonatal respiratory and 57% cardiac patients with disease). 3 In the NRCPR retrospective review of extracorporeal life support, 81% of patients with sepsis, 100% of patients with pneumonia, and 85% of patients with renal insufficiency died. 4 There is a lot of variability for indications for E-CPR from institution to institution, with debate over which patients are E-CPR candidates. In selected cardiac patients, CPR with good neurologic outcome is unlikely especially in patients with hemi-Fontan/bidirectional Glenn 35 physiology, and pulmonary hypertension in whom it is difficult to get adequate cerebral perfusion and pulmonary blood flow during CPR. Whether patients with sepsis, pediatric respiratory disease, hemi-Fontan/bidirectional Glenn, and pulmonary hypertension benefit from ECMO remains to be tested, but most positive outcomes have resulted from implementation of extracorporeal support during the low cardiac output state recognized and treated prior to cardiac arrest.

sec.title: The Future of CPR and E-CPR Research?
sec.p: The future of CPR and E-CPR research includes rapid recognition and deployment, improving vascular access, high-quality basic life support, titration of blood flow, oxygen and ventilation to optimize brain and heart function, assessment of long-term neurologic outcomes of survivors, with increased attention to validated quality-of-life assessments, and development of evidence-based neuroprotective strategies. Enhancing the quality of CPR, especially in the neonatal population with development of feedback devices similar to those developed for older children, 13 is another area that requires investigation. Correlating the quality of CPR with outcomes is another area for future research. The postresuscitative care phase, with further strategies to enhance neuroprotection is being studied, we look forward to seeing the results of the “Therapeutic Hypothermia after Pediatric Cardiac Arrest (THAPCA) 40 ” multicenter trial, in which children who had a cardiac arrest are being randomized to receive therapeutic hypothermia versus controlled normothermia. In addition, with the increasing use of E-CPR, use of neuroprotective strategies on ECMO is another area ripe for investigation.

fn.p: The author(s) declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
The author(s) received no financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
Presented at the Seventh International Conference on Pediatric Mechanical Circulatory Support Systems and Pediatric Cardiopulmonary Perfusion, Philadelphia, USA; May 5–7, 2011.
